Article.ArticleTitle: Development of an Activated Carbon-Based Electrode for the Capture and Rapid Electrolytic Reductive Debromination of Methyl Bromide from Postharvest Fumigations.

AbstractText: Due to concerns surrounding its ozone depletion potential, there is a need for technologies to capture and destroy methyl bromide (CH<sub>3</sub>Br) emissions from postharvest fumigations applied to control agricultural pests. Previously, we described a system in which CH<sub>3</sub>Br fumes vented from fumigation chambers could be captured by granular activated carbon (GAC). The GAC was converted to a cathode by submergence in a high ionic strength solution and connection to the electrical grid, resulting in reductive debromination of the sorbed CH<sub>3</sub>Br. The GAC bed was drained and dried for reuse to capture and destroy CH<sub>3</sub>Br fumes from the next fumigation. However, the loose GAC particles and slow kinetics of this primitive electrode necessitated improvements. Here, we report the development of a cathode containing a thin layer of small GAC particles coating carbon cloth as a current distributor. Combining the high sorption potential of GAC for CH<sub>3</sub>Br with the conductivity of the carbon cloth current distributor, the cathode significantly lowered the total cell resistance and achieved 96% reductive debromination of CH<sub>3</sub>Br sorbed at 30% by weight to the GAC within 15 h at -1 V applied potential vs standard hydrogen electrode, a time scale and efficiency suitable for postharvest fumigations. The cathode exhibited stable performance over 50 CH<sub>3</sub>Br capture and destruction cycles. Initial cost estimates indicate that this technique could treat CH<sub>3</sub>Br fumes at ∼$5/kg, roughly one-third of the cost of current alternatives.
